lessonOverview.title: Unit 5 - Lesson 2
structures: A: Is it a new camera? / Is it an old bag?
B: Yes, it is. / No, it isn’t.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six personal items (camera, bag, umbrella, skipping rope, puzzle, picture) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show flashcards of personal items. Say: “This is a skipping rope.” Students repeat and then identify in the SB.
stretchStrategies: Mystery Bag Game (No bag needed) – Say: “I’m thinking of something. It’s small and new. Is it a puzzle?” Students ask Yes/No questions using the target structure (“Is it a big picture?”, “Is it a new skipping rope?”). Once they guess correctly, they take over as the clue-giver. Use flashcards or drawn pictures if needed for support.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
